Package uk.co.zodiac2000.subscriptionmanager.service

Class AuthorizationService

java.lang.Object
uk.co.zodiac2000.subscriptionmanager.service.AuthorizationService
@Service @Transactional(readOnly=true) public class AuthorizationService extends Object
Service responsible for identifying subscribers where the authorization identification requirements are satisfied by the authentication identifiers supplied by the client.

  • Method Details

    • getSubscribersByOidcIdentifiers

      public Set<SubscriberResponseDto> getSubscribersByOidcIdentifiers(OidcIdentifierRequestDto oidcIdentifierRequest)
      Returns subscribers that are associated with an OIDC identifier where the issuer and all the OIDC claims match the values of those fields in oidcIdentiferRequest. Where the request contains multiple values then a match occurs if any value matches the value associated with the subscriber's OIDC identifier.

      For example, if a Subscriber's associated OIDC identifiers are: 
       [
  {
   issuer: "http://example.com",
   oidcIdentifierClaims: [
    {claimName: "groups", claimValue: "staff"},
    {claimName: "fs-site", claimValue: "Brighton"}
   ]
  },
  {
   issuer: "http://example.com",
   oidcIdentifierClaims: [
    {claimName: "groups", claimValue: "admin"}
   ]
  }
 ]
      This request representing the claims submitted by a client will match the subscriber because it includes the claims required to match the first OIDC identifier. Note that the sub claim was not required to identify the subscriber. 
       {
  issuer: "http://example.com",
  oidcIdentifierClaims: [
   {
    claimName: "groups",
    claimValues: ["staff", "member"]
   },
   {
    claimName: "fs-site",
    claimValues: ["Brighton"]
   },
   {
    claimName: "sub",
    claimValues: ["43792473"]
   }
  ]
 }
      This request representing the claims submitted by a client will match the subscriber because it includes the claims required to match the second OIDC identifier. 
       {
  issuer: "http://example.com",
  oidcIdentifierClaims: [
   {
    claimName: "groups",
    claimValues: ["staff", "admin"]
   }
  ]
 }
      This request representing the claims submitted by a client won't match the subscriber because it doesn't match the fs-site claim. 
       {
  issuer: "http://example.com",
  oidcIdentifierClaims: [
   {
    claimName: "groups",
    claimValues: ["staff", "student"]
   },
   {
    claimName: "fs-site",
    claimValues: ["Shoreham"]
   }
  ]
 }
      Note, the representations used above are to illustrate how a subscriber is identifier and are not exactly the same as the object model.
      Parameters:
      oidcIdentifierRequest - request DTO the contains the issuer and claims submitted by the client
      Returns:
      zero or more matching subscribers
